key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What actions can be taken to reduce predation by marine mammals at aquaculture systems?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several actions can be taken to reduce predation by marine mammals at aquaculture systems.
[Statement 2]: Replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation.
[Statement 3]: Using acoustic devices at aquaculture systems was effective in some studies.
[Statement 4]: Four out of six studies found that acoustic devices reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions.
[Statement 5]: Four out of six studies found that acoustic devices reduced the number of harbour seals approaching fish cages.
[Statement 6]: Translocating mammals away from aquaculture systems was not effective.
[Statement 7]: Two studies found that more than half or nearly all of Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returned.
[Statement 8]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of modifying aquaculture gear at aquaculture systems.
[Statement 9]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of modifying anti-predator nets at aquaculture systems.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of minimizing food waste at aquaculture systems.
[Statement 11]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of introducing regulations to prevent harmful deterrents at aquaculture systems.
[Statement 12]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of introducing legislation to prevent the intentional killing of mammals at aquaculture systems.

[Statement 1]: Deploying fishing nets at different depths is effective at reducing marine mammal entanglements.
[Statement 2]: Fishing nets deployed 4.5 m below the water surface in the Arafura Sea had fewer entanglements of dolphins than surface nets.
[Statement 3]: Using acoustically reflective fishing gear materials can reduce entanglements.
[Statement 4]: Fishing nets made from acoustically reflective materials like iron-oxide or barium sulfate had fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises than conventional fishing nets.
[Statement 5]: Nets made from barium sulfate did not reduce dolphin entanglements.
[Statement 6]: The use of weakened fishing gear has not been evaluated in studies for marine mammal populations.
[Statement 7]: Establishing move-on rules for fishing vessels when marine mammals are encountered can reduce marine mammal mortality.
[Statement 8]: Introducing measures in the Great Australian Bight to delay or relocate fishing if dolphins were encountered resulted in fewer short-beaked common dolphins being encircled and killed.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__Which modifications to fishing gear are most effective at reducing marine mammal entanglement?
fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the population-level effects of legally protecting marine mammal species or their habitats?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Legally protecting marine mammal species and their habitats shows several population-level effects.
[Statement 2]: Studies on habitat protection for marine mammals found mixed but generally positive effects.
[Statement 3]: Mediterranean monk seal populations increased after eight years of island protection.
[Statement 4]: Bottlenose dolphin populations maintained similar sizes before and after habitat protection.
[Statement 5]: Hector's dolphins showed higher survival rates after coastal area protection.
[Statement 6]: Human-caused strandings decreased after area protection.
[Statement 7]: Overall strandings remained similar after area protection.
[Statement 8]: Four out of five studies found that the abundance of marine mammals increased after hunting bans.
[Statement 9]: The populations of harbour seals and humpback whales increased over a period of 7 to 30 years after hunting bans.
[Statement 10]: Ten of twelve baleen whale populations showed significant increases during the 7 to 21 years after protective legislation was enacted.
[Statement 11]: No studies were found that evaluated the direct effects of legally protecting marine mammal species themselves.
[Statement 12]: One study found no significant change in the number of mature male sperm whales 31 years after a hunting prohibition.

[Statement 1]: The evidence base for interventions to reduce lethal vessel collisions with marine mammals is extremely limited.
[Statement 2]: Setting and enforcing vessel speed limits is the only intervention type that has been evaluated in any studies.
[Statement 3]: Two before-and-after studies have examined the intervention of setting and enforcing vessel speed limits.
[Statement 4]: One study on vessel speed limits was conducted in the Indian River estuarine system in the USA.
[Statement 5]: One study on vessel speed limits was conducted in the North Atlantic Ocean in the USA.
[Statement 6]: The Indian River study found that the number of manatee deaths was similar before and after vessel speed limits were set in 'zones'.
[Statement 7]: The Indian River study found there were fewer manatee deaths after speed limits were set and enforced in all areas.
[Statement 8]: The North Atlantic study found that setting vessel speed limits during specific periods in key habitats resulted in fewer deaths of North Atlantic right whales caused by collisions.
[Statement 9]: All other intervention types for reducing lethal vessel collisions with marine mammals have no evidence base.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found for the intervention of using observers on board vessels.
[Statement 11]: No studies were found for the intervention of diverting shipping routes.
[Statement 12]: No studies were found for the intervention of implementing regulations.
[Statement 13]: No studies were found for the intervention of providing vessel operator training.
[Statement 14]: No studies were found for the intervention of modifying vessels.
[Statement 15]: No studies were found for the intervention of using remote detection tools.
[Statement 16]: No studies were found for the intervention of using real-time automated detection tools.
[Statement 17]: No studies were found for the intervention of using technology and reporting systems.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What is the state of the evidence for interventions aimed at reducing lethal vessel collisions with marine mammals?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Based on studies from the Pacific and Tasman Sea regions, translocation outcomes for marine mammals vary significantly depending on conservation goals.
[Statement 2]: In the North Pacific Ocean, studies on Hawaiian monk seal translocations for population re-establishment showed positive outcomes.
[Statement 3]: Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had 50-83% survival rates.
[Statement 4]: The survival rates for translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups were similar to or greater than non-translocated pups.
[Statement 5]: More than a quarter of translocated Hawaiian monk seals reproduced.
[Statement 6]: Translocated Hawaiian monk seals exhibited similar dispersal behavior to native-born pups.
[Statement 7]: Studies in the Tasman Sea focused on conflict reduction showed poor outcomes.
[Statement 8]: When Australian and New Zealand fur seals were translocated away from salmon farms, more than half or nearly all of the seals returned to the original sites.
[Statement 9]: Translocating Australian and New Zealand fur seals away from salmon farms was an ineffective approach for reducing human-wildlife conflict.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__How do the outcomes of translocating marine mammals vary depending on the conservation goal, based on studies from the Pacific and Tasman Sea regions?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence from 27 studies on marine mammal rehabilitation and release shows variable long-term survival outcomes.
[Statement 2]: Twenty-one studies with post-release monitoring found that 10-100% of dolphins, porpoises, whales, seals, sea lions and manatees survived after being released following rehabilitation.
[Statement 3]: The monitoring periods for the twenty-one studies on rehabilitated marine mammals ranged from three days to five years.
[Statement 4]: One controlled study found that at least 25% of California sea lions treated for toxic algae poisoning and released back into the wild died or had to be euthanized.
[Statement 5]: A study demonstrated that more than 25% of rehabilitated and released Hawaiian monk seals reproduced.
[Statement 6]: Eleven studies on the rescue and release of stranded or trapped marine mammals found survival rates of 17-100%.
[Statement 7]: The post-release monitoring periods in the eleven studies on stranded or trapped marine mammals ranged from three weeks to three years.
[Statement 8]: Studies on rescued and released marine mammals found that rescued and released common bottlenose dolphins were observed with calves one year later.
[Statement 9]: Hawaiian monk seal rescue and release, along with other interventions, resulted in more than 25% of the seals surviving and reproducing.
[Statement 10]: Two controlled studies showed that rehabilitated and released harbour porpoises and harbour seals had similar movements and behaviours to wild mammals.
[Statement 11]: One study found that California sea lions treated for toxic algae poisoning showed altered behavior compared to wild sea lions.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What is the evidence for the long-term survival of marine mammals following rescue or rehabilitation and release?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several actions are available to reduce human-wildlife conflict at commercial fisheries in riverine systems.
[Statement 2]: Acoustic devices deployed on moorings can reduce harbour seal predation on migrating juvenile salmon.
[Statement 3]: Anti-predator nets around aquaculture systems can be replaced or repaired more frequently to reduce salmon losses to harbour seal predation.
[Statement 4]: Barriers such as 'cork line' barriers can be installed at wild fisheries.
[Statement 5]: One study found that installing 'cork line' barriers did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon.
[Statement 6]: Switching off artificial lighting at wild fisheries is a tested option to reduce human-wildlife conflict.
[Statement 7]: One study found that switching off artificial lighting did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon.
[Statement 8]: Translocating mammals away from aquaculture systems has been attempted.
[Statement 9]: Studies found that more than half or nearly all of translocated Australian and New Zealand fur seals returned.
[Statement 10]: Modifying aquaculture gear and anti-predator nets are potential actions to reduce human-wildlife conflict.
[Statement 11]: No studies have evaluated the effectiveness of modifying aquaculture gear and anti-predator nets.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What actions are available to reduce human-wildlife conflict at commercial fisheries in riverine systems?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Studies found that 50-83% of translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups survived for at least one year.
[Statement 2]: Translocated seal pups had similar survival rates to non-translocated pups born at release sites.
[Statement 3]: Translocated seal pups had greater survival rates than non-translocated pups remaining at the original site.
[Statement 4]: Translocated pups exhibited similar dispersal times to non-translocated seal pups born at release sites.
[Statement 5]: More than a quarter of translocated Hawaiian monk seals reproduced after translocation combined with other survival interventions.
[Statement 6]: More than a quarter of rehabilitated and released Hawaiian monk seals successfully reproduced.
[Statement 7]: More than a quarter of seals survived after translocation when implemented along with at least seven other interventions to enhance survival.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What is the evidence for the success of interventions like translocation and rehabilitation for Hawaiian monk seals in the North Pacific Ocean?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Non-lethal alternatives for managing marine mammal presence and predation at aquaculture facilities include acoustic devices, translocation, and physical barrier modifications.
[Statement 2]: Acoustic devices at aquaculture systems showed mixed effectiveness.
[Statement 3]: Some studies found that acoustic devices reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals, and South American sea lions.
[Statement 4]: Some studies found that acoustic devices reduced the number of harbour seals approaching fish cages.
[Statement 5]: Other studies found that acoustic devices did not reduce harbour seal predation around fin-fish farms.
[Statement 6]: Other studies found that acoustic devices did not reduce bottlenose dolphin presence around fin-fish farms.
[Statement 7]: Replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation.
[Statement 8]: Translocating mammals away from aquaculture systems was ineffective.
[Statement 9]: More than half or nearly all of Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returned to the area.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of modifying anti-predator nets at aquaculture systems.
[Statement 11]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of modifying aquaculture gear.
[Statement 12]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of minimizing food waste at aquaculture systems.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the non-lethal alternatives for managing marine mammal presence and predation at aquaculture facilities, and how effective are they?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several non-lethal methods have been tested for reducing seal predation at wild fisheries.
[Statement 2]: Acoustic devices have shown significant promise across multiple studies for reducing seal predation.
[Statement 3]: Deploying acoustic devices on moorings reduced the number of harbour seals feeding on migrating juvenile salmon in the Puntledge River in Canada.
[Statement 4]: At aquaculture systems, acoustic devices reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals, and South American sea lions.
[Statement 5]: Using acoustic devices on fishing gear reduced seal damage to fish catches and fishing nets in multiple controlled studies.
[Statement 6]: Physical gear modifications have proven effective for reducing seal predation.
[Statement 7]: Modifying fishing pots and traps to exclude mammals with wire grids or steel bars reduced damage to salmon catches by grey and harbour seals.
[Statement 8]: Using strengthened netting on fishing pots and traps reduced damage to salmon catches by grey and harbour seals.
[Statement 9]: Installing steel rods or metal frames on fishing pots and traps reduced the number of grey and harbour seals that entered or became trapped in the pots.
[Statement 10]: Electric deterrents showed positive results in one controlled study.
[Statement 11]: Using an electric current on a fishing net reduced Pacific harbour seal predation on salmon catches.
[Statement 12]: Switching off artificial lighting at wild fisheries failed to deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery.
[Statement 13]: Installing cork line barriers failed to deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery.
[Statement 14]: Playing predator calls was ineffective at deterring Cape fur seals.
[Statement 15]: Visual deterrents showed mixed or no effects on marine mammals.
[Statement 16]: Acoustically reflective objects showed mixed or no effects on marine mammals.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the most beneficial non-lethal methods for reducing human-wildlife conflict at wild fisheries involving seals?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Management actions that can reduce disturbance to marine mammals from tourism and recreational activities include introducing and enforcing regulations for marine mammal watching tours.
[Statement 2]: Studies showed that when whale-watching vessels followed approach regulations, fewer whales changed their behaviours or avoided vessels compared to when regulations were not followed.
[Statement 3]: Fewer Guiana dolphins displayed negative behaviours when tour boats followed regulations.
[Statement 4]: Setting limits or prohibiting the feeding of marine mammals by tourists can reduce disturbance.
[Statement 5]: One study found that after limits were set on feeding, the survival of bottlenose dolphin calves increased to match the survival of calves from non-fed mothers.
[Statement 6]: Training tourist guides to minimize disturbance is a management action that can reduce harm to marine mammals.
[Statement 7]: One study in Alaska found fewer harbour seals were disturbed during kayak excursions after guides received training.
[Statement 8]: Limiting vessel speeds is a management action to protect marine wildlife.
[Statement 9]: Evidence suggests lower vessel speeds cause fewer injuries to animals.
[Statement 10]: Lower vessel speeds allow animals more opportunity to flee from approaching vessels.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What management actions can reduce disturbance to marine mammals from tourism and recreational activities?
fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the documented effects of translocating marine mammals for different conservation purposes?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The documented effects of translocating marine mammals for conservation purposes are primarily focused on population re-establishment and boosting efforts.
[Statement 2]: Four studies evaluated the translocation of Hawaiian monk seals to re-establish or boost native populations in the North Pacific Ocean.
[Statement 3]: Studies on Hawaiian monk seal translocation demonstrate varying outcomes.
[Statement 4]: Survival rates showed that 50-83% of translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups survived for at least one year.
[Statement 5]: Rehabilitated and translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups showed similar survival rates of 52%.
[Statement 6]: When compared to non-translocated populations, translocated seal pups had similar survival rates to pups born at release sites.
[Statement 7]: Translocated seal pups showed greater survival rates than pups remaining at original sites.
[Statement 8]: More than a quarter of translocated seals reproduced following interventions that included rehabilitation and survival enhancement measures.
[Statement 9]: Translocated seal pups exhibited similar dispersal behaviors to non-translocated pups born at release sites.
[Statement 10]: Currently, no studies have been found documenting effects of moving mammals before impactful activities.
[Statement 11]: No studies have been found documenting the effects of relocating marine mammals following oil spills.
[Statement 12]: No studies have been found documenting the effects of translocating marine mammals to reduce disease exposure.

[Statement 1]: The current state of evidence regarding actions to reduce pollution from land-based agricultural and municipal sources affecting marine and freshwater mammals shows a significant knowledge gap.
[Statement 2]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of treating wastewater from intensive livestock holdings on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
[Statement 3]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of reducing pesticide, herbicide or fertilizer use on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
[Statement 4]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of establishing riparian buffers to reduce pollutant runoff on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
[Statement 5]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of creating artificial wetlands to reduce effluent reaching water bodies on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
[Statement 6]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of setting or improving minimum sewage treatment standards on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
[Statement 7]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of limiting storm wastewater overflow on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
[Statement 8]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of establishing aquaculture to extract nutrients from agricultural runoffs on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
[Statement 9]: No studies were found evaluating the regulation of agrichemical use specifically for marine mammals.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found evaluating limiting storm wastewater overflow specifically for marine mammals.
[Statement 11]: The lack of studies means there is currently no evidence to indicate whether pollution reduction actions are effective or have any harmful impacts on marine and freshwater mammal populations.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What is the state of the evidence regarding actions to reduce pollution from land-based agricultural and municipal sources affecting marine and freshwater mammals?
fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__What are the most beneficial interventions for reducing marine mammal bycatch in Australian fisheries?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Establishing handling and release protocols for captured mammals is a beneficial intervention for reducing marine mammal bycatch in Australian fisheries.
[Statement 2]: A study in the Great Australian Bight found that establishing handling and release protocols reduced mortality of short-beaked common dolphins when combined with avoiding dolphins during fishing.
[Statement 3]: Deploying fishing gear at different depths is a beneficial intervention for reducing marine mammal bycatch.
[Statement 4]: A controlled study in the Arafura Sea found that nets deployed 4.5 meters below the surface had fewer dolphin entanglements than surface nets.
[Statement 5]: Establishing 'move-on rules' for fishing vessels when mammals are encountered is a beneficial intervention for reducing bycatch.
[Statement 6]: A study in the Great Australian Bight found 'move-on rules' resulted in fewer short-beaked common dolphins being encircled and killed when combined with releasing trapped dolphins.
[Statement 7]: Using acoustic devices on fishing vessels is a beneficial intervention for reducing marine mammal bycatch.
[Statement 8]: Multiple studies in Australian waters, including Rainbow Channel and Keppel Bay, showed acoustic devices can reduce dolphin foraging and echolocation activity.
[Statement 9]: The effects of acoustic devices on marine mammals vary by species and behavior type.
[Statement 10]: Using catch and hook protection devices can reduce unwanted catches of toothed whales.
[Statement 11]: Using catch and hook protection devices can reduce damage to fish catches.
[Statement 12]: Using acoustically reflective fishing gear materials is an intervention for reducing marine mammal bycatch.
[Statement 13]: Some studies found acoustically reflective fishing gear materials reduced harbor porpoise entanglements.
[Statement 14]: The effectiveness of acoustically reflective fishing gear materials varies by material and species.
[Statement 15]: Interventions like gear exchange programs, low-interest loans for gear conversion, and fisher involvement in gear design have been proposed to reduce marine mammal bycatch.
[Statement 16]: The proposed interventions of gear exchange programs, low-interest loans for gear conversion, and fisher involvement in gear design lack evaluation studies to confirm their effectiveness.

[Statement 1]: The evidence for mitigating seal predation shows distinct approaches between aquaculture systems and wild fisheries.
[Statement 2]: In aquaculture systems, replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation.
[Statement 3]: Using acoustic devices at salmon farms reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions.
[Statement 4]: The effectiveness of using acoustic devices at salmon farms to reduce seal predation varied, with two of six studies showing no reduction in predation.
[Statement 5]: Translocating mammals away from aquaculture systems showed limited effectiveness.
[Statement 6]: More than half or nearly all of translocated Australian and New Zealand fur seals returned to salmon farms.
[Statement 7]: For wild fisheries, evidence on mitigating seal predation focuses on gear modifications.
[Statement 8]: Installing steel rods on lobster pots or metal frames on fishing pots reduced seal entrapments.
[Statement 9]: Installing wire grids or steel bars on fishing trap-nets or bag-nets, along with strengthened netting, reduced damage to salmon catches by seals.
[Statement 10]: The use of wire grids, steel bars, and strengthened netting on fishing nets resulted in higher catches of undamaged salmon.
[Statement 11]: Switching off artificial lighting at wild fisheries did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon.
[Statement 12]: Playing predator calls did not deter Cape fur seals from feeding on fish catches.
[Statement 13]: No studies were found on enforcing regulations to prevent harmful deterrents at wild fisheries.

key: fireworks_kimi-k2-0905__How does the evidence for mitigating seal predation differ between aquaculture systems and wild fisheries?
